speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, with your permission, I will change directions. Perhaps if the Hon. Minister stays, we could have that exchange later. Mr. Speaker, Hon. Members of the House of Commons, I am honoured to have this opportunity to address the House as we debate the Speech from the Throne. As I begin my tenure, I would like to express my deepest appreciation to the electors of Mount Royal for placing their trust in me.
At the outset, Mr. Speaker, 1 want to add my personal congratulations and sincere best wishes to you on your new responsibilities. Yours will not be an easy task but you will have the confidence and respect of all Members here. I also wish to pay a special tribute to the other 26 women elected to this Parliament. Ours is the largest number ever elected in Canadian history.

subsubtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext: Hear, hear!

subsubtopic: RESUMPTION OF DEBATE ON ADDRESS IN REPLY
speechtext:
Our numbers have confirmed a more acceptable and nobler meaning to the cliche, "a woman's place is in the house". I wish us all wise counsel in this House as we add our particular perspectives to those of our partners.
In speaking of a woman's place in this House, let me congratulate the Government upon its selection of a delightful young woman as the seconder to the Speech from the Throne. As well, let me offer my felicitations to the mover.
In a sense, the riding of Mount Royal needs no introduction in the House. It has a long and honourable history of sending outstanding Members to this Parliament. In the last 35 years, two men have sat in this Chamber on behalf of the people of Mount Royal. Alan MacNaughton was the Member from 1949 to 1965. He sat in your chair for three years, Mr. Speaker, and served with great distinction. The Hon. Member for Mount Royal prior to the last election was, of course, well known to all Canadians. He was the Right Hon. Pierre Elliott Trudeau, one of the outstanding Canadians of this century. His passion for Canada, its unity, its diversity and its future, was matched only by his passion for world peace and stability. With this tradition and legacy of leadership from Mount Royal, I am both humbled and challenged by the prospect of succeeding representatives such as these two outstanding Canadians.
My riding mirrors much of what is great in this country. The riding is composed of four sectors: Cote St. Luc, the Towns of Mount Royal and Hampstead and parts of the Montreal Districts of Snowdon and Cote-des-Neiges. About
88,000	people make their homes there, and one out of every five is over the age of 65. The Hon. Minister can understand my concern.
The major cultural group in Mount Royal is Jewish, accounting for 48 per cent of the riding. We are indeed proud that our riding is almost 60 per cent bilingual and is enriched by many diverse ethnocultural communities, weaving a wonderful multicultural tapestry. As for mother tongue, 52 per
The Address-Mrs. Finestone
cent are English while 21 per cent are French. As for ethnic origin, people from the four corners of the world, from the Caribbean Islands, Chile, South Africa, southeast Asia, the Middle East and Europe, all make their homes here.
In the best of Canadian traditions, cultural pluralism and social commitment are at the forefront in Mount Royal. Human rights here and throughout the world are a major concern for the members of this well-informed and generous community.

Internationally, the respect of the Canadian Government for human rights has been expressed in many ways; in its assistance to political refugees in Central America and to those suffering from famine in Ethiopia; in its support for Soviet Jewry; and in its support for the security of Israel. It is our voice as well in the United Nations. It is my sincere hope that the new Government maintains and enhances these vital initiatives in support of international human rights.
At home our concerns with human rights have been just as strong. Here our concerns with the rights and opportunities of individuals have properly focused on two groups of society of particular importance to my constituents and myself, women and youth. This focus must continue. There must be a continuity of purpose and action. In recent weeks, government Ministers have repeatedly talked of "sending new signals" to different groups in our society; signals to the private sector; to labour, to the Americans; to our NATO Allies; and to the world with respect to peace. I want to look to this Throne Speech to see what signals the Government is sending to the women, to the youth of Canada and to the cultural communities.
The evolution of the role of women in Canada, their growing awareness, strength and constructive action is most important. I am pleased to see that the apparent willingness of the Government to address the concerns of women is manifest. However, I must warn the Government that Canadian women-and men-will not be satisfied with words alone. Only three things are needed to follow up on the rhetoric of the Throne Speech, action, action and action. Under the Liberal government women have made great progress. This Government has a really tough act to follow.

Women can and must become full partners in our society both economically and socially. They will reach that goal not only through legislative changes, but also through changes in attitude on the part of the Canadian people and the business sector.
However, economic independence is the very basis of women's equality. We challenge the Government to follow in the footsteps of the previous Liberal Government and at least keep up the pace at which it defended the rights of women.

November 15, 1984
The Address-Mrs. Finestone

Change, Mr. Speaker, must begin at the very centre of government decision-making, in Cabinet's own Priorities and Planning Committee. It seems incongruous that the Minister responsible for the Status of Women is not a bona fide Member who participates directly in the discussions and decisions of this key group. The Government risks the charge that its attention to the significant concerns of Canadian women is little more than tokenism, for it excludes them from the heart of policy-making.
Thus far, the gaps between campaign promises and the reality of the Throne Speech are troubling, Mr. Speaker. First, employment; the promise was for mandatory affirmative action in the public sector and for implementing equal pay for work of equal value. The promise was for contract compliance in the case of companies seeking federal government contracts. The Throne Speech now tells us that the reality is further study of equal pay for work of equal value. The reality is silence on contract compliance.
Second, child care is a basic right for women in their struggle for economic independence. It is a cornerstone of their right to work. The Government has sent a confused and alarming message to Canadian women in its overly cautious decision to send these questions to a parliamentary committee when the recommendations of an independent childcare task force are to be tabled this December. Before trying to reinvent the wheel and waste public monies, this parliamentary committee should examine the reports available from these experts whose work on the childcare task force is about to be ended, and then make the decision as to whether it really needs to continue the study.
[ Translation]
Third, there is the crucial issue of the pension system. Must I remind this Government that only one third of Canadian working women have a pension plan? Will they be added to the poorest group in our population, women aged over 65? The necessary studies and consultations have already taken place under the previous Government. What Canadien women ask this Government is that it act now.

Fourth, the concern about pornography is a matter of urgency. When the Fraser report is tabled, swift action by Government must follow. Similarly with the important Badg-ley Commission report on sexual abuse of children in Canada. We must work with the courts, the provinces, and with medical and community groups to prevent child abuse. There are helpful steps to take at once, sending a signal of hope.
Fifth, we should not forget single elderly women. Community responsibility, which was alluded to in the Speech from the Throne, gives reference to community-based health care, which is a genuinely laudable notion. The Government should assure elderly citizens of appropriate financial, social and medical care so that they can remain in their homes, continuing to be active and contributing members of society. Do not
tamper with the universality of certain programs which form the base of their sense of security.
[ Translation]
In this regard, the decision of the Government to extend the survivor's allowance to widows and widowers aged between 60 and 64 is a step in the right direction. However, the fact remains that the Government should have a more comprehensive view. Such a proposal discriminates against single senior citizens. Among them are 200,000 women who would not be eligible to pension before the age of 65.

These are the women's issues which were addressed in the Throne Speech, Mr. Speaker. I regret to say that the signal to women in the Throne Speech is a "blue alert". What has the Government really told us it would do? It will re-examine the concept of equal pay for work of equal value; back off on affirmative action; procrastinate on contract compliance; study rather than act on child care; discuss rather than act on pension reform; take no major action in agriculture which affects so many farm women; cut $9.6 million in social housing. These things are all crucial to the life of millions of Canadians, particularly Canadian women, be they single parents, those with large families or the elderly. These are not encouraging signals, Mr. Speaker. This really is a Government of broken promises.
What signals is the Government sending to the young? It does not give them the crucial hope of pursuing their studies or finding a good job to see them through this winter and the forthcoming summer. It gives them a Minister of State for Youth who is responsible for furthering the International Year of Youth and has only the power to advocate in their interests, in other words, a Minister who cannot protect their potential for jobs now. Where is this Government's promise of jobs, jobs, jobs? The Government abolishes the Summer Canada Program and freezes the level of Canada student loans to save $5 million. Among other cuts, it eliminates totally the Young Workers' Exchange Program, which I find particularly ironic in this International Year of Youth. The discussion paper on training announced by the Minister of Employment and Immigration (Miss MacDonald), by which she hopes to promote consultation with the provinces, may develop a good long-term plan. Nonetheless, this must not constrain short-term action and direct job creation to avoid a very bleak winter.
Besides providing direct job creation programs, the previous Government made major strides in the area of training. For all its talk of giving hope to Canadians, this Government offers obscure promises in some dim future. To ignore the immediate needs of unemployed youth is short-sighted and a mockery. This is not the change they voted for.
While my official position is that of critic for women and youth, I cannot let this moment pass without a comment on our cultural minorities. The Canadian idea is complex. It is our native people, it is French and English. It is the wealth of cultures that more recent Canadians have brought us. To this
November 15, 1984

wealth the Speech from the Throne gives a dismissive nod in three lines. There was no promise to reintroduce the Multi-cul-turalism Act. Cultures in exile from their home soil need nurturing. This Government does not seem to feel this. If the Government does not perform, it will let Canada's rich cultural tapestry grow threadbare, and we really must fight this.

However, I am disappointed, as are so many, that it has failed to follow up on the acknowledgement with any evidence of immediate action. The Government has sent the signal all right; it has sent an alarm signal that said "stop" to all those efforts under-way to remove the barriers and to extend an opportunity for women and young people. For this reason the Throne Speech has fallen short of expectations of Canadians for change. In the months ahead we will demand more than signals. We will expect action; action on contract compliance, affirmative action, pension reform, child care, pornography, prevention of family violence as well as the reintroduction of the Bills on divorce and multiculturalism, on jobs, education and training for youth. Along with my colleagues I plan to be the "porte-parole" of the grass roots in this House.

Women's issues and youth issues cannot be dealt with in isolation from larger economic and social decisions. Rather, they must run to the very core of what governmental decision making is all about. Members: We will be vigilant in seeing that it does prevail in order to uphold a tradition of social action and commitment that speaks to the very best of Canada and Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the Hon. Member. Her reputation for interest in women's issues and for her commitment and involvement in this House precedes her.
As to the question, I must say I heard the Hon. Member make that recommendation the other day. My immediate reaction was; My goodness, what a marvellous idea. Then I sat back and thought for a few minutes. I cannot give a concrete response but I can tell the Hon. Member what my thoughts were. I place this before her and I would be happy to speak with her later.
Women have lived for a very long time in isolation from the mainstream of decision making. We have fought long and hard for equal representation as partners in today's society. We are finally making it. We are now 26 in this House. Every issue which touches humanity, our concern, are men and women issues. Therefore it is my feeling that, when it comes to the legislative process, I personally-I cannot speak for my colleagues because I have not discussed it with them-wish to sit with my partner, the man in my life, the men with whom I live, the men who are going to share the society which we will build, to make what would seem to be the best decision for society as a whole.
This does not in any way, in my view, remove the need for a concerted effort on the part of women in a separate kind of place to look at the issues. If the Hon. Member is saying to me, let us have a standing committee, I would say no, because the tendency in society is then to dump everything there that concerns women. I do not want to isolate women in that way. What happens to them touches the whole world.
If we want to vet all legislation coming through covering farmers, fisher ladies and fishermen, all legislation, then yes, but in an unofficial way, then I would be happy to join her and on that I might agree with her. I think in a sense I have made a decision while talking to the Hon. Member.

I am blessed with four sons, one of whom is in the Gallery, and 1 am delighted to note that. Some of my sons have chosen to marry, some have not. Some of my daughters-in-law have chosen to have children, some have not. Some choose to pursue a career, some do not. However, all these women and these men qualify as femininsts. Mr. Speaker, first I would like to congratulate you and your staff on your new appointments. I am sure the people in Sherbrooke are delighted with the decision made by the Right Hon. Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney).
I would like to say a few words about the two Hon. Members who spoke before, and first of all I would like to congratulate the Hon. Minister of National Health and Wei-
November 15, 1984

fare (Mr. Epp), the Member for Provencher, on his clear and concise statement, and also the Hon. Member for Mount Royal (Mrs. Finestone) on her balanced and sincere comments that were certainly worth listening to.
"La Beauce" has chosen me as its elected representative, and I therefore wish to express my gratitude to the people in my riding and thank my constituents for their confidence and trust. 1 can assure them that I shall perform my duties to the best of my ability. I intend to be fair and to help everyone in my riding, irrespective of their past political affiliations. It is a great honour for a citizen to be elected to the Parliament of his country.
It is the first time I have had the honour of addressing this House, and with its Members, both experienced parliamentarians and those who are new to this Chamber, I intend to behave with the dignity that befits a Member of Parliament. I have the privilege of being the first Progressive Conservative Member to be elected in Beauce in exactly 100 years. I wish to pay special tribute to all parliamentarians who in the past have taken up the cause of the people of Beauce in this House. The people of Beauce have pride, dignity and courage, and I intend to be an effective and also demanding spokesman in defending their interests.
Mr. Speaker, the federal riding of Beauce is quite large, covering 4,215 square kilometers. At the last census it had a population of 82,000. There are about 55 towns. The geography of this area is quite distinct from that of other ridings in Quebec and reflects the warmth of its people. The economy is based on agriculture, forestry and a host of small industries. In Quebec, my riding is described as a paradise for small- and medium-sized businesses. A diversified economic base has helped this area to avoid industrial concentration in one specific sector, and the attendant risks. The energy and creativity of the people in this area have helped to create what is referred to as the "miracle beauceron". Mr. Speaker, these people nevertheless have problems and sometimes have to go to the Government for assistance. However, their attitude is best described by the following saying: God helps those who help themselves. The people of Beauce are often referred to as the Japanese of Quebec. We are indeed honoured!
In Quebec, there are two kinds of people: those who are Beauceron and those who would like to be. In the House, we have Progressive Conservatives and a couple of others who would like to be Progressive Conservatives. If only the rest of the country had the same vitality we find in the people of Beauce, the same spirit of entrepreneurship shown by our business people, our skilled and conscientious workers and our 3,700 productive farmers, the same desire to compete with regions that have a lot more resources!
I am sure the former President of the United States, John F. Kennedy, was thinking of people like the people of Beauce when he told the Americans:
The Address-Mr. Bernier
"Don't ask what your country can do for you but ask what you can do for your country". Agriculture is vital. It was Canada's first, and for many years, chief economic lever. Today, although farmers are fewer in number, they have learned to produce bigger and better harvests.

Generally, "la Beauce" is a rural area that is rather well structured. The Hon. Minister of Agriculture (Mr. Wise) will have to understand the farmers in my constituency. I trust him to do this.
"La Beauce" is also a world-renowned maple-sugar area. The maple-sugar industry is extremely successful there. Indeed, our maple syrup production accounts for 30 per cent of the world market. However, that industry will have to be subsidized as far as the processing, marketing and export of that seasonal product are concerned. Also, good forest management could help the economic growth of this area.
The Hon. Member for Beauce, like 170 other Conservative Members, does not yet have the privilege of being a Minister. But I would like you to know, Mr. Speaker, that in our party there are no backbenchers, no rank and file Members, but Members of Parliament who already have a prime role to play in Government decisions. Our action will be a positive one. In the Conservative caucus, Hon. Members can get action on issues. Our views will be respected. We belong to a great political party, an open and generous party where co-operation is felt between French- and English-speaking Members, a truly national party.
Let me say also that this country has a role to play on the world scene, and we will make an international contribution. The position upheld by this Government concerning monetary, food and technical assistance to the victims of drought in Ethiopia has been a great joy to me. The Right Hon. Minister for External Affairs (Mr. Clark) and the Hon. Minister for External Relations (Mrs. Vezina) have set up a national aid committee for that country. Mr. Speaker, let me emphasize that Third World countries which soon will include three quarters of the population, will also obtain financial help, because, according to the findings of the Commission on International Development under the chairmanship of Mr. Willy Brandt in 1980, the global income is shared unequally between the various nations, and there is a wide gap between industrialized and poor, developing countries. Per capita income is 32 times greater and the average life expectancy is thirteen years longer in richer countries than in Third World countries. The gap between nations and peoples has reached such proportions that it is seriously endangering the global economy. It is one of the major factors that make the global crisis more acute and affect the political climate.
286

November 15, 1984
The Address-Mr. Bernier

Shortly before his death, the great American scientist, Robert Oppenheimer, said that when the vast numbers of people living today on the verge of famine and utter hopelessness become aware of what their situation is and what our situation is, "I am afraid to think what will happen".
I want to stress that social and economic development in the Third World is not only a condition for the prosperity of the industrialized nations, it is an irreversible movement.
In its Throne Speech the Conservative Government traced the broad outline of the action it plans to take. We will not hesitate to innovate as the session continues. We are responsible for the future of the country's economy. We are discarding outworn dogmas and we intend to pursue a new strategy of national development that will free Canada's economy from the dead end in which it is currently trapped. The new economic order will ensure prosperous and continuing development.

Therefore, we must adopt a new perspective and do away with those old-fashioned ideas in order to grasp the spirit of an ever changing world.
The often bitter comments of our friends opposite will not hinder our efforts and prevent Government Members from thinking, acting and carrying out our great objectives for the well-being of every Canadian.
The former government, in fighting inflation through restrictive monetary and budgetary means, slowed down the economic growth during the last decade to an average rate of 2.3 per cent. Because of this, unemployment had reached a critical level when we came into power.
As Peter Drucker, the eminent journalist of the Wall Street Journal, says in his book "Towards A New Economy": "We must acknowledge the need to go back to making difficult choices. Politicians must deal with a number of difficult structural and political choices, hence the need for proceeding with budgetary cutbacks."
Here are the questions the Government must ask itself. "What percentage of the national income should be transferred from producers to non-producers, in other words, from those who create employment and those who depend on the State? What limits should be set on public spending? What percentage of national income can be allocated to funds available for remuneration of employment rather than capital, without increasing unemployment and economic depression? What tax bonuses and financial stimuli are necessary to build the requisite capital?" Our Government is demonstrating great courage and determination because .. . "These are not popular questions. Any answer is bound to lead to controversy, and there is a risk involved because it is a constant reminder that there is a price to pay for everything. It is a matter of facing up to reality and the need to make choices. Economics has
again become a sinister science, a science of limits, risks and choices. This was in fact the opinion of the famous economist, John Maynard Keynes: "It is not enough to understand new ideas. We must also escape the old ones that have extended their ramifications in every nook and cranny of our minds."
Mr. Speaker, I want to stress the fact that from now on, a new vision of the world will be necessary, a global and system-oriented vision, because every economy is dependent on other countries. The need for a new vision is particularly great in view of the close and increasing interdependence of the world's countries in their economic and financing activities. As a result of this interdependence, the problems of a single country become international problems, and their solution must therefore be solved within the international context.
For instance, developing countries are in great need of our goods and services, and industrialized countries, like Canada, will need these countries more and more in order to operate at full production capacity, which will help us fight unemployment.
It would be useful to consider some of the new ideas set forth by Professor Angelo Angelopoulos of the Academy of Athens, in his book "A World Employment Plan", which contains a foreword by the Nobel Prize winner Lawrence Klein.
Mr. Speaker, I feel the Conservative Government is on the right track. If they take a closer look at the Throne Speech and last week's economic statement by the Hon. Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson), I am sure Canadians will appreciate the proposed measures.
My constituents in Beauce will never suffer financially as a result of the decisions made by this Progressive Conservative Government. We shall protect programs and vested rights. The Hon. Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) has explained to Canadians the precarious economic situation of this country and, as a first step, proposed a plan to restructure our expenditures, a plan that has already been endorsed by the vast majority of Canadians. By creating a new climate of confidence across Canada, this plan will promote productive investment which will bring the growth rate of our economy up to 3.4 per cent by 1990.
We are committed to building a national consensus. The economic summit will determine our objectives, as the Right Hon. Prime Minister said. In Beauce, I shall try to encourage and support investors, those who create jobs and are prepared to take investment risks for the benefit of the community.
The Speech from the Throne also refers to a new responsiveness of the Government vis-a-vis the provinces. I am particularly pleased with the co-operation offered to Quebec. Quebecers have felt frustrated as a result of a long period of difficult
November 15, 1984

negotiations with Ottawa. Since September 4, a day of national liberation, the results have been swift and effective. The federal machine is no longer set to seek confrontation and jurisdictional disputes. Harmony is the order of the day, Mr. Speaker. Personally, I am convinced that the leader of our Party and the leader of this Government has had a great deal to do with it. His talents as a mediator, his flexibility and his desire to put an end to these federal-provincial quarrels have been an important factor in creating this new climate.
Mr. Speaker, together we are starting a new era, and these men and women who form our new Government deserve the confidence and support of Canadians. I live in and represent a marvellous part of the country: "la Beauce". I shall be making a constant effort to help my constituents. I shall defend their claims and try protect their vested rights and fulfil my mandate with fairness, equity and common sense.
Mr. Speaker, the Member for Beauce wishes to thank you for your attention and assure you of his co-operation.

Whatever universality means, I will take their meaning for it. They say they want universality, and then at the same time they say we should continue borrowing. They say that we should borrow ourselves out of debt. They are doing away with social services. The aged, the veterans and the widows who depend upon social services are not dumb, to use street language. They know that social services depend upon the productivity of the country.
This Government is determined to increase productivity. The more we increase productivity, the better social services we can give to our people. It is as simple as that.
The Liberals borrowed and borrowed and borrowed. They kept up social services with borrowed money. Generations to come will now have to pay interest on it for many, many years; today we are paying $1 out of every $3. How wonderful it would be if we could give that $1, instead of to the money-mongers of the world, to the hard-pressed widows who have three or four children to look after, to the farmer who will lose his farm or to senior citizens, the crippled or mentally retarded. These are the people for whom we have compassion. We are determined that the sick, incapacitated and mentally disturbed will receive the best in this country. Our Leader will ensure that they get the best because we are reducing the
November 15, 1984

deficit. Then we will be able to increase our productivity and provide more social services all the way around.
Those Hon. Members talk about borrowing themselves out of debt, which is what some other countries in the world tried to do. I ask them to stop and think where they are going and what they are doing to the country. No wonder there is such a handful of Members in the NDP and Liberal Party. Canadians were sick and tired of their borrowing themselves out of debt. They know that it cannot be done. They might as well try to pull themselves up by their bootstraps. Let us see anyone do it. It cannot be done. The NDP has been trying to do it for years. The Liberal Party tried to do it all the years it was over here. What happened? We paid more and more interest, so that now there is a legacy of debt around the neck of every baby born in the country. Every baby boy is born with a $6,000 of debt, brought about by the Liberals and supported by the NDP.

speechtext: Mr. Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I wonder whether the Hon. Member knows that he is using sexist language and discriminating against baby girls when he makes statements like that.

speechtext:
I will talk about discrimination, Mr. Speaker. The NDP and the Liberals are the ones who discriminate against baby girls, because baby girls are being bom with a debt of $6,000 around their necks too. We are the ones who are looking after the baby girls, the baby boys, the mentally retarded, the crippled and the aged. We intend to do it. The policies in our economic statement and in the Speech from the Throne will increase productivity and jobs and will give us greater amounts of money to provide social services to those who need them, not to those who do not need them.
The people of Canada saw the light at the end of the tunnel. They put their X beside the names of 211 members of the Progressive Conservative Party because they wanted change. They wanted a new government and a new look at things. They wanted to do away with borrowing ourselves out of debt. They wanted us to start paying our bills like any respectable family.
1 cannot understand the philosophy of the NDP and the Liberal Party. They think they can continue borrowing, borrowing, borrowing. That cannot be done by individuals. They would get to the point where they would lose their homes, their farms, everything. We cannot borrow ourselves out of debt, and we will not try. We will increase productivity. We will have more work for people. We will pay our debts and eventually be rid of that deficit or public debt. That is the heritage we want to give the boys and girls, the men and women of the country. Our Leader has a vision. Progressive Conservatists have a vision of a new country, working together from the Atlantic to the Pacific, from the forty-ninth parallel to the Arctic, with everyone of all colours and creeds happy. It will be a buoyant economy in which we share what we have with the helpless of the world. I admire this philosophy.
I would like to deal with one or two local problems. I was absolutely amazed at how the Liberal Government, month after month, did nothing about the importation of beef. It did
The Address-Mr. Taylor
nothing. It just sat on whatever it sits on and did nothing for eight months. Look at the amount of beef that came into the country in the meantime, 145.1 million pounds of beef, mostly from Ireland. It did not come in on a fair market basis. It was subsidized to the point of 38.5 cents per pound by the Irish Government. This subsidy came out of the pockets of the poor Irish people in order that this beef could be dumped into Canada.
Our Government sat here and took it. What did that do to our industry? It almost destroyed our cattle industry. What did it do to our neighbours to the south and to Australia which should have had a share of that quota? We have built up a terrible record.
The Americans have every right to say that we want to export into the United States, but we will not allow imports of U.S. beef into Canada. No, we let it all be dumped in at a subsidized rate. It hurt our industry and hurt our best neighbours, the United States and Australia.
What machinery did the Government have to deal with this? They cannot say that nothing could be done. Several of the Members of this Party spoke to the Government when we were on that side of the House. We urged the Government to do something under the anti-dumping legislation. The then Government did not do a thing until August when the then Minister of Agriculture saw the light. He said that something had to be done because we were destroying our relationship with our good neighbours as well as destroying the cattle industry in Canada. That is what we were doing. He went to the Anti-Dumping Tribunal and asked them to look at the situation.
Let me deal for a moment with the Anti-Dumping Tribunal. Many people do not know that we have this tribunal or the Anti-Dumping Act. That Act was passed in 1969 for the sole purpose of keeping our industries from being ruined by subsidized products from other countries. That is why the Act was established. It takes into account a number of factors, including a share of the market profits, prices, export performance, productivity and employment. It takes in all of those things. Linally, after eight months, the Minister referred it to the Anti-Dumping Tribunal. Who is on the Anti-Dumping Tribunal? I have to tell you because it is important that Members know who they are. The Chairman is Robert Bertrand, the Vice-Chairman is Howard Perrigo. The Members are Raynald Guay, A. L. Bissonnette and Margaret R. Prentis. They could appoint as many as six. I do not know any one of them personally, so I do not speak personally. I am speaking about the principle.
If that tribunal had said, yes, it is hurting our industry in Canada, it is hurting our relations, hurting our employment, hurting our cattle industry and hurting our markets, then the Deputy Minister could have imposed a penalty on the beef being imported from Ireland to the amount that it was being subsidized, namely, 38.5 cents a pound. If that had happened,

November 15, 1984
The Address-Mr. Taylor
there would be no imports. They would have stopped immediately.
That is what the Liberal Government should have done. That Government let it go on and on until the whole quota was taken up. At that point our new Government was left helpless. The quota has been used up.
This PC Government will not permit that to happen again. Never will that happen again. I cannot understand how the Anti-Dumping Tribunal could say that this was not injuring the cattle industry in Canada, not injuring our markets and not injuring our relationships. As far as I am concerned, that Anti-Dumping Tribunal should be thrown out. They did not do their job. When they said there was no injury done by the dumping of that beef into Canada, they were not doing their job. If I had the say, they would be out of there right away. I would put somebody in there who understands the different industries of this country.
As a result of imports and a few other things, such as drought and grasshoppers, the cattle industry across Canada is in pretty bad shape. In my own province, in my constituency, the cattle industry is pretty worried, as are many grain farmers, because the drought stopped the wheat, rye and barley from growing. It stopped the growth of feed. Our cattlemen have no feed. Governments are now coming to their aid. Our Minister signed an agreement to provide some help. Help is forthcoming.
If Members opposite do not think that grasshoppers can do a lot of damage, they should have been in southern Alberta this summer. When I was electioneering, the front of my car was completely green with grasshoppers. When I was a kid, I liked to find green grasshoppers. I always caught bigger fish with green grasshoppers. This year you would not have had to hunt for them. There were millions of them. They even attacked a house. They would eat a garden in no time at all. They came almost like a cloud. Don't laugh, people had to move out of their houses. As a result, the cattle industry is in bad shape.
This money will help. They will have enough money to buy feed for 40 to 60 days. However, these cattle will have to be fed for 100 to 120 days. What will happen? They will have to sell some of their cattle. Normally, they would have to pay income tax on the sale of the cattle.
I have a suggestion for the Minister of Agriculture (Mr. Wise). Along with making proper use of the Anti-Dumping Act, and because of the terrible situation on the farms in southern Alberta, the recommendation of the cattle industry should be accepted. If a farmer has to sell some cattle in order to feed the rest, he should have a deferral of taxes on that income. They do not suggest a forgiveness, but a deferral. Cattlemen are not asking for forgiveness, they are simply asking for a deferral. In two or three years when the situation returns to normal, they will be able to buy back their cattle and pay their taxes.
Cattlemen are independent. They want to pay their way. They want to build this country. However, they do not like to be destroyed by beef being dumped into this country.

Hundreds of thousands of small independent entrepreneurs will be making their own decisions. That is what will build Canada.
That is the way this Government is tackling the problem right from the grass roots. It is not using band-aids, not at all. We are taking out what is bad and building from the grass roots up. In that way, we will help our entrepreneurs. Productivity is what our Leader has in mind. When we have great productivity, we will have great social services. The crippled, the lame, the senior citizens and the widows will not have to worry. They will receive better treatment from us than they ever received under a Liberal Government.

subtopic: CANADIAN RADIO-TELEVISION AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION-LONG DISTANCE TELEPHONE HEARINGS. (B) TELECOMMUNICATIONS POLICY-REQUEST FOR COMMITTEE REVIEW
CANADIAN RADIO-TELEVISION AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION-LONG DISTANCE TELEPHONE HEARINGS. (B) TELECOMMUNICATIONS POLICY-REQUEST FOR COMMITTEE REVIEW
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am somewhat surprised because I was told that I would be the third on the list tonight. However, I am ready to proceed.
On November 13, I addressed a question to the Minister of Communications (Mr. Masse). I pointed out to him that the CRTC was considering an application made by the CN-CP Telecommunications System to permit them to enter into the long distance telephone business. I asked the Minister whether he would consider suggesting to the CRTC that it should not
November 15, 1984

issue any statement on this application until a telecommunications policy had been set by the Government. To my amazement, the Minister refused to agree to that suggestion.
I say that I was amazed because on August 17 of this year, the present Prime Minister (Mr. Mulroney) addressed a telegram to the Telecommunications Workers Union of British Columbia in which he said the following:
The Progressive Conservative federal caucus has been examining and consulting widely on the serious implications of this application. We have identified as the first problem the absence of a comprehensive telecommunication policy for Canada, within which this question could be fairly assessed.
We believe that the first step must be the development of a comprehensive policy which includes a clear understanding of consumer needs, historical relationships, technological opportunities, and impact on federally and provin-cially-regulated telephone services.
He went on to say:
In the absence of a clear federal policy, including any vision of how future consumer and business needs and opportunities should be balanced in Canada, it will be difficult for the CRTC to assess the application for de-regulation of long distance telephone services, in hearings scheduled for autumn, without a policy framework.
That is precisely what I was urging the Minister to do. I did so because we know from studies which have been done that if CN-CP Telecommunications is permitted to enter into long distance service in competition with the existing telephone systems, like Bell Canada in Ontario and Quebec, B.C. Tel in British Columbia, the three publicly-owned provincial systems in the prairie provinces and the systems in Atlantic Canada,
600,000	users across the country would give up their telephones, because telephone rates would increase by between 70 per cent and 125 per cent. Many people would find it extremely difficult to absorb that increase. The winners would be the large corporations of the country, the major users of long distance service. The banks, insurance companies and other large corporations use the telephone system frequently and even daily. They would be the real gainers.
I suggest that it is wrong for the CRTC to proceed for another reason. Under our legislation, the CRTC has the right to monitor and set rates for Bell Canada, which services Ontario and Quebec, and for B.C. Tel, which services the Province of British Columbia. However, it does not have the legal right to set the rates for the systems which service Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta. Yet, Mr. Speaker, these three provinces now benefit from this present system. These three provinces with their telephone systems receive a large part of their revenue from the long distance calls which are made not only from within their provinces but from calls, for example, from British Columbia to Toronto or Montreal. If those calls provide a profit for the telephone system, those profits are shared with all of the systems, and the prairie provinces receive a large part of their revenue from those long distance calls. Because of the money they receive from long distance calls, they have been able to keep the rates as low as possible for the ordinary home owner, the farmer and the small business person. For that reason they have had almost 97 per cent usage among potential telephone customers.
Adjournment Debate
If CN-CP is permitted to enter into the business in competition with the existing system, naturally it will get part of the business and, naturally, the existing systems will have to reduce their long distance rates to compete. Revenues will go down and the losses suffered will have to be made up by increasing the rates to the present user.
I agree, Mr. Speaker, with what the Prime Minister said when he was the Leader of the Opposition, that this question should not be settled at this time by the CRTC but should be a policy decision by the Government. I know the legislation says that the CRTC has the authority and responsibility for dealing with the application. I am not suggesting that it should not deal with it. I am saying, Mr. Speaker, that it ought not to release its decision until the Government has worked out a telecommunications policy.
It may be that when the Government does that, Mr. Speaker, many people in Parliament and groups and organizations outside of Parliament will disagree with the telecommunications policy of the Government. However, that policy will have been established by a Government which is elected by the people and not by a quasi judicial agency which, in my view, has not the right to make that kind of decision. And the CRTC will be doing that, Mr. Speaker, if it permits the CN-CP Telecommunications to enter into the long distance telephone business.

speakeroldname: Mr. Geoff Scott (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Communications):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Communications
subtopic: CANADIAN RADIO-TELEVISION AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION-LONG DISTANCE TELEPHONE HEARINGS. (B) TELECOMMUNICATIONS POLICY-REQUEST FOR COMMITTEE REVIEW
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to discuss the issue of interexchange competition and the proceedings being conducted by the Canadian Radio Television and Telecommunications Commission on this matter. As the Hon. Member will know, considerable debate has been generated in connection with this proceeding and there exists a great deal of confusion with respect to the issues which are now being considered by the Commission. For example, some parties believe that a decision by the Commission in favour of CN-CP Telecommunications would result in a U.S.-style deregulation and the introduction of local measured service. On the contrary, CN-CP contends that it is prepared to pay compensation for the use of telephone company facilities which would be used to offset increases in local rates.
In the course of the proceedings there have been various estimates made regarding increases in local telephone rates. Similar estimates relate to the number of people who would be forced to drop off the network-give up their telephone-if local rates were to be increased. Most of these estimates are based on experience in the United States.
The fact of the matter is, Mr. Speaker, that there is no application before the Commission to provide local measured service or to deregulate telephone rates. In the United States there are a number of factors simultaneously at play which are affecting telephone rates in that country. For example, the break up of the Bell system has resulted in a massive restructuring of the telephone network. It has also resulted in the need to develop new regulatory and costing procedures. These

November 15, 1984
Adjournment Debate
factors and others are generally referred to as "deregulation". However, most of the U.S. telecommunications sector remains subject to regulation.
We all know, Mr. Speaker, that our proximity to the United States can often expose us to the effects of that country's policies. Over the years we have learned to develop unique Canadian solutions to deal with such eventualities. The proceeding that is underway before the CRTC is part of that process. The proponents and opponents of the CN-CP proposal have submitted evidence to support their points of view. There is also the opportunity for cross-examination. Out of this orderly but time-consuming process will come a solid factual record, based on which the CRTC will render its decision on the merits of the CN-CP case. The Government, in developing its policies for the telecommunications sector, will draw on that information base as well.
The telephone network has served Canadians in all walks of life for more than 30 years. In the past 20 years, it has become much more than a telephone system. The network now connects computers, terminals, and word processors on a worldwide basis. It is now more than ever an indispensable tool of modern business. At the same time, the policies and regulations applying to the industry are rooted in the past.
It is therefore appropriate that the Government should review telecommunications policy. The Department of Communications is currently engaged in this task. Public submissions have been received, and discussions are being held with interested parties. The CRTC hearings will also provide an important input to the Department's review.
The Government is fully aware of the importance of the telephone service to Canadians and is very mindful of the social benefits which they derive from it. Therefore, while the Government is of the view that Canada's telecommunications system and the regulatory structure must undergo adjustments in order to respond to changing needs and new requirements, it is also firmly committed to preserving affordable, universally available telephone service in all regions of Canada.

subtopic: MARINE TRANSPORT-FERRY SERVICES IN ATLANTIC CANADA. (B) GOVERNMENT SUBSIDIES

speakeroldname: Mr. Brian Tobin (Humber-Port au Port-St. Barbe):
subtopic: MARINE TRANSPORT-FERRY SERVICES IN ATLANTIC CANADA. (B) GOVERNMENT SUBSIDIES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, over the last two days I have had an opportunity to address questions to the Minister of Transport (Mr. Mazan-kowski) regarding the $37 million in cuts announced Thursday last by the Minister of Finance (Mr. Wilson) affecting the Department of Transport, and in particular the gulf ferry services of Atlantic Canada.
The people of Atlantic Canada regard the ferry services in their province, particularly those in Newfoundland and P.E.I., both island provinces, as an extension of the Trans-Canada Highway. When we are talking about gulf transport, whether it be between North Sydney and Port aux Basques, or North Sydney and Argentia, between P.E.I. and Nova Scotia, we are
not talking about an alternate means of transportation or the scenic route by the sea. For the average Canadian living in those island provinces, and for the average small businessman operating in those island provinces, we are talking about the only economically viable means of moving goods and people for the people of Atlantic Canada.
The Minister today admitted in this House that the increase proposed by CN to Cabinet will be triple that submitted as of early September. That is an increase of 15 per cent to be imposed in the next few weeks, versus an increase proposed as part of the proposed mandatory six and five program of 4 per cent. The Minister told us that we should not feel too badly; after all the Government is going to put a new ferry on the service which will be much better. It is called the Caribou. I beg to inform the Minister that the Caribou has been under construction for a year. This is nothing new. There are an additional two boats coming into service and they have been underway, as the Parliamentary Secretary nods his head knowingly, for the last couple of years as well, in terms of planning. So you cannot justify 15 per cent cost increases simply on the basis that we are going to have new vessels which are more efficient, bigger and therefore, folks, you are getting a better service and you should pay more.
The fact is that when one looks at the increased cost to users of the facilities currently offered anywhere in this country by Crown corporations in the transport business, nowhere else in Canada other than Atlantic Canada are increases of the magnitude of 15 per cent being imposed. The Minister has indicated that we should not worry, that the rate is 15 per cent but that for regular users there is going to be a discount, and it will only be 5 per cent or 6 per cent. Mr. Speaker, I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary what a regular user is.
Will the discount apply to small business people who use the ferry services, not to move luxury items up the Labrador coast or on the south coast of Newfoundland or between P.E.I. and Nova Scotia or Nova Scotia and Newfoundland or New Brunswick and P.E.I., but to move basic foodstuffs, the basic necessities?
Will the additional freight charges which I am told will also be in the order of 15 per cent, apply to food and to those companies which bring their supplies in by way of ferry or gulf boat service? If that is the case, Mr. Speaker, not only are consumers in Atlantic Canada going to be asked to pay 15 per cent more when they avail of CN Marine, because they are not regular users, but they are going to be asked to pay 15 per cent more on the transportation portion of the cost of a tin of spaghetti, a loaf of bread, eggs, or fresh milk, every time they go to the supermarket. Mr. Speaker, for those island provinces in particular, that would be totally unacceptable. That will set up two systems of citizenship in this country.
There is another matter about which I am very concerned. Over the last day I have had the opportunity to speak to union representatives of railway workers and people working on the Gulf and Coastal Ferry Services and the employees of those
November 15, 1984

agencies. To this point they have not been consulted. The Parliamentary Secretary comes from Atlantic Canada and knows about the 25 per cent levels of unemployment in North Sydney and Port-aux-Basques. Perhaps he can tell us what the job loss will be. Perhaps he can tell us when the Minister will get around, in this new age of consultation and co-operation, to discussing this with the people most directly affected by cutbacks and rate increases. How many jobs are going to be lost? What frequency of service is going to be introduced? What kind of reductions are going to be imposed?
In closing I would like to say that I am pleased with the choice of the gentleman who has been named as Minister of Transport (Mr. Mazankowski). He is a very knowledgeable man. There is no one in the Government Party who can hold a candle to the kind of experience and knowledge that he has in this field. I want to wish him every good luck in his duties. Over these last few years I have heard him speak eloquently about the regional sense of frustration and the resulting disunity in western Canada. The seeds for that kind of divisiveness exist in Atlantic Canada. They exist in particular when actions are taken without consultation and without regard to the kind of hardships they can impose, in particular on people in island provinces who have no alternate means of transportation to resort to.
1 have had the pleasure of knowing the Parliamentary Secretary since 1980 and I know that he will ensure that the Minister has an Atlantic view. I hope he will begin today by telling the House and the people of Atlantic Canada that he is going to ensure that food and basic necessities being moved on those ferries and on the gulf run will not be subject to a 15 per cent increase which is a double tax on everyone in Atlantic Canada. I hope he will tell me as well that either himself or his Minister will begin tomorrow to consult the people who will be affected first and perhaps most; the employees of CN Marine in Atlantic Canada.

speakeroldname: Mr. J. M. Forrestall (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Transport):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
subtopic: MARINE TRANSPORT-FERRY SERVICES IN ATLANTIC CANADA. (B) GOVERNMENT SUBSIDIES
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, there is certainly no question that the Minister of Transport (Mr. Mazankowski) is probably the most knowledgeable man in this Chamber and one of the most knowledgeable men in Canada with respect to transport matters in this country. I can assure the Hon. Member that he does have an Atlantic view.
Ferry and coastal services in Atlantic Canada constitute an area of very substantial federal Government expenditures. It constitutes $178 million to $180 million, not including some
Adjournment Debate
$13 million to $14 million invested in CN Marine this year to support its current program of new facilities and the construction of the Motor Vessel Caribou.. The users of these services contribute in fares and tariffs about 22 per cent of the over-all costs.
The Government has made decisions which will reduce substantially its expenditures in 1985-86 and beyond, while at the same time increasing the efficiency of the services through the provision of new and more productive vessels and support facilities.
The modernization of the Newfoundland ferry and coastal fleet will improve service to passengers and freight customers through the introduction of fewer but larger and faster vessels. Changes in rates and levels of service in the CN Marine Altantic ferry network will be implemented following consultation with regional interest groups and others affected.
Users of all the services will be asked to contribute more to the costs in order to reduce the burden on all Canadian taxpayers for services provided. Government officials will therefore be discussing with the operators measures that can be taken to increase their revenues by 15 per cent, effective April 1, next year. Frequent users of the services, as the Member has pointed out, will also be afforded an opportunity to apply for reduced fares. Hopefully, after consultation, these matters will improve what the Hon. Member was talking about.
An increase of 15 per cent in CN Marine rates would represent four one-thousandths of a cent per pound for a tractor trailer with a 40,000 pound payload travelling in these services. I have used the Prince Edward Island service as an example. We will assess the ability of CN Marine's St. John-Digby ferry service, and the Hon. Member has raised this, to handle truck traffic diverted from the Bluenose during the winter months. Until the fall of 1985, the Bluenose service will operate year-round between Yarmouth, Nova Scotia and Bar Harbour, Maine. Afterward, it will operate for six months a year in the tourist season as a money saving measure.
The addition of modern ferry vessels on the Newfoundland Gulf and Coastal Service will have an extremely positive impact on the people of our particular part of the country.
I see the gentleman at the Mace, so I will conclude.
